name: Wednesday Multi-Agency Drop In

children.text: A one stop drop-in service runs every Wednesday afternoon from 1pm to 4pm at the Victoria Hall in Sheffield city centre. A range of services are present including Assist, Red Cross, Migrant Help, City of Sanctuary, Snowdrop Project. They will try to answer questions about services, provide information, help and signposting. Interpreters are present, but there is no guarantee that a interpreter for a particular language will be available. A conversation club is run at the same time. See printable resources for a list of monthly attendees.

address: Victoria Hall (Main Church Entrance), Norfolk Street, Sheffield

name: G4S Care and Justice Services

children.text: G4S provides accommodation (initial accommodation, and dispersed accommodation) and transport services for destitute asylum seekers (section 98, section 95 and section 4) in Yorkshire, the Humber and the North East, under a Home Office COMPASS contract. Services are delivered directly or via subcontracted accommodation providers in the region. The email address can be used for reporting incidents, complaints or contacting any member of the G4S COMPASS team. The following areas are covered Barnsley, Bradford, Calderdale, Doncaster, Hull, Kirklees, Leeds, Rotherham, Sheffield, Wakefield, the North East.

address: G4S COMPASS, Carlton House, Carlton Road, Worksop

name: Home Office Further Submissions Unit (FSU)

children.text: Asylum seekers can submit new evidence if their asylum claim has been refused and they have no more right to appeal. This is called a 'further submission'. All further submissions made on protection grounds following the refusal of asylum or humanitarian protection must be made in person at the Further Submissions Unit (FSU) in Liverpool. Claimants must make an appointment to attend the FSU unless they fall into one of the exceptional categories. The FSU operates an appointment only system. To make an appointment, individuals must contact the FSU. The FSU will send written confirmation of the appointment (by letter or e-mail) to the individual, including the address of the FSU and a link to the form on the Gov.UK website (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/further-submissions-asylum-humanitarian-protection-discretionary-leave). Claimants should complete the form and bring it to their appointment in Liverpool.

phone: Appointment line: 0151 213 2411 Monday to Friday, 9am to 4pm
address: Postal address: Further Submissions Unit , The Capital, New Hall Place , Liverpool  L3 9PP /  Physical address: Level 1, 6 Union Street, Liverpool, Merseyside, L3 9AF

name: Asylum Support Appeals Project (ASAP)

children.text: Asylum Support Appeals Project (ASAP) reduces destitution amongst asylum seekers by protecting their legal rights to food and shelter. They offer free legal representation and advice to asylum seekers and refused asylum seekers appealing against the Home Office decisions to refuse or withdraw their housing, financial subsistence, or both. They provide asylum support advice and training to frontline organisations, advice agencies and legal practitioners working with asylum seekers. Refugee community organisations and other voluntary agencies who are advocating on behalf of asylum seekers about their asylum support / asylum support appeals can call their Advice Line on 0203 716 0283. name: Framework Street outreach team

children.text: Framework's Street Outreach Team serves two main purposes: to engage with and help rough sleepers and to quantify the extent of street homelessness in partnership with other agencies such as local authorities. Working in Nottingham, Nottinghamshire and Sheffield, team members are at the front line of the fight against rough sleeping and street homelessness. They work in the early hours of the morning in order for them to identify those in the greatest need of support. Street Outreach helps rough sleepers or those faced with the prospect of sleeping rough to: Find safe and secure accommodation Find appropriate treatment for underlying drug, alcohol and mental health problems Secure access to medical help Re-engage with estranged family members Return to their home region of home country Claim whatever benefits they may be entitled to

name: Sunday Centre

children.text: The Sunday Centre is a not-for profit organisation which serves the homeless and vulnerable in Sheffield City Centre. On Sundays, there is a particular need for a safe, warm refuge available to all as many of the other relief organisations working in Sheffield close on this day. Our main aim is to provide hot food and drinks, yet we also offer our guests a genuine welcome and the chance to socialise with others as they wish. The sessions are run in Victoria Hall Methodist Church, using the entrance on George Street for access (see “Our Location” for a map and directions). From 1.30 pm onwards, we run a tea/coffee bar with biscuits and cup-of-soups available. Guests are also able to chat among themselves or with volunteers, read books & newspapers and play board games or snooker. At 2.00 pm a two-course hot lunch is served, prepared on site by our volunteer kitchen team. Our sessions close at 4.00 pm.

address:
Victoria Hall
Norfolk St, Sheffield

children.text: Sheffield Churches Soup Kitchen have supported and cared for the vulnerable and needy of our city for the past 30 years. We are based on King Street and provide food and support 7 nights per week between 8 and 9pm. Typically, food includes hot drinks, sandwiches, crisps, cakes and biscuits. We also provide dog and cat food to those who need it. We take a small amount of clothing, bedding and footwear just in case we find someone who really needs them.

name: Working Win

children.text: Working Win

are running The Health-led Employment Trial which is an experimental trial testing a new employment support service for people with a health condition. The trial aims to find out how good this new service is at helping people to find and stay in work, and is now live. Anyone registered with a GP in South Yorkshire or Bassetlaw is eligible to apply.
The service comprises:
One-to-one support to suit needs and employment goals
Help finding a job if not in paid employment, and continued support once starting work
Help to continue working if struggling to manage a health condition at work
Benefits advice to find out if work could increase income
Help talking to employesr about needs at work
Meetings over the phone or in person at a convenient location
To can refer by e-mail, telephone or by filling in
this form

name: ATLEU

children.text: The Anti Trafficking and Labour Exploitation Unit (ATLEU) is a charity providing legal representation to victims of trafficking and labour exploitation, assisting victims to obtain safety, recovery and redress.

ATLEU delivers a comprehensive and dedicated service which includes: advising victims on their immigration status and assisting them to apply for asylum or other forms of lawful residence; securing appropriate and safe accommodation, financial support and treatment from local authorities, the Home Office or other statutory bodies; and obtaining compensation from their traffickers or the state.
ATLEU has a Sheffield Office but this office is for prior appointments only. Contact ATLEU via their advice (advice@atleu.org.uk) or referral e-mail (referral@atleu.org.uk).

children.text: This service is for children who are unaccompanied and have claimed or have the intention to claim asylum and have been trafficked to, within or outside the UKor are victims of modern slavery.
Direct support for children and young people who are victims of trafficking as well as advice, support and training for professionals working with them.

Direct support for trafficked children, focusing on their safety and protection while supporting them through the various legal and other processes which they have to undergo. We also offer advice to others involved in their care.
Direct and personalised one-to-one support for children and young people who are victims of trafficking across England including:
support, advice and advocacy through the asylum and trafficking processes​support and advocacy through the criminal justice system
support and advocacy through the age dispute process
liaising with and facilitating access to other services including legal representatives, social services, law enforcement, education and healthcare
accompanying to appointments and support with orientation and life skills

Provides mutual aid style support for refugees and asylum seekers in Sheffield staffed by experienced volunteers (jan.thompson@sheffield.cityofsanctuary.org)
The Connections Team -

SPRING Move-On support -
Provides move on support for refugees recently given leave to remain in the UK (blessan@sheffield.cityofsanctuary.org)
